title: Are Latter-day Saints offended by others who drink tea or coffee in public (without intending to make a show of it, just to drink it)? - Quora
tags: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons)

response.answer_text: TLDR: Mormons don’t mind your coffee. As long as you don’t judge us for saying no. I can’t speak for all Mormons, though I’m guessing that my point of view is somewhat common. I don’t drink coffee or tea, but don’t really fault anyone else for doing it. If they weren’t prohibited by my beliefs, I’d probably be all over it too. Salt Lake City (not my hometown) even has a few hot chocolate cafes, allowing Mormons to pseudo-participate in the attractive café experience. Most of us don’t care about your coffee. Truth is, we might even be a little jealous. The attitude is a little different about alcohol. From a distance, I see how it could be useful as a “social lubricant” and occassional escape, and getting soused looks like it could even be fun sometimes. But I’ve also seen firsthand how much alcohol complicates and sometimes destroys lives. A lot of violence, crime, poverty, familial abuse, accidents, death and imprisonment wouldn’t exist without the help of alcohol. And since my life seems pretty great and fulfilled without having touched a drop, I ask myself, “Why does society seem to rotate so heavily around this stuff?” I mean, if you take the just-landed-alien-researcher point of view, you might realize how heavily our culture leans on alcohol to help us have a good time, as if our brains weren’t capable of experiencing pleasure without it. So to a Mormon, alcohol can be sometimes perplexing, sometimes annoying, sometimes infuriating. But most of the time, it’s just whatever. Drugs are another level entirely. With the exception of marijuana, which kind of sits at or below the level of alcohol, drugs are a no-go. Too much addictive and destructive power there. Which leads to a final point: addiction. Because we don’t drink coffee, tea or alcohol, do drugs or smoke, Mormons are in a position to think that the rest of you people are silly to succumb so easily to your addictions. Of course that would be hypocrisy. Because most of us would be just as hooked on coffee or wine or whatever, and we’d defend it just as passionately, if we’d only ever started.

No. Seriously, no. We (Mormons) make covenants with God. One of these is known as the Word of Wisdom found in Section 89 of the Doctrine and Covenants. You can read it online here: Doctrine and Covenants 89. Non-Mormons, ie: Everyone else on the planet, are under no such covenant and can act for themselves. Many of the answers here point to this already; and likely better than I could explain. So I’ll add a little color commentary from my childhood. For background, I was raised Mormon in “The South” or the southern United States for our international friends- this is not the Mormon mecca that Utah or Arizona are. I was taught, from probably before I could walk, that smoking and drinking alcohol, tea, & coffee was bad. Story 1 - Coffee: I was a slow learner in school. Reading, in particular, was hard for me to pick up on. I had a private reading teacher for a couple years in early elementary/primary school. My teacher was an “old” (to a 6 year old every adult is old) Jewish woman. She was the best! She gave prizes and had fun, simple books for me to read, etc. One lesson she had brought a mug of coffee out onto her deck to nurse while we had a lesson. Being an ignorant, self-righteous child, I told her it was bad and asked her to please move it where I wouldn’t have to smell it. Yep, that was me…super intolerant, know-it-all, HUGE jerk. She was nice enough to oblige me and only explained the situation to my mom when she came to pick me up. My mom was polite and spoke to me later…part praise for recognizing what it was and that I shouldn’t have any…mostly discipline for presuming to tell an adult anything. Story 2 - Tea: When I was 9–10ish I was at a family reunion. This was a yearly event but this year would prove to be “special”. Our extended family would rent out a fellowship hall of a community church in a very rural area. My immediate family would travel for close to 2 hours to get from “the big city” to this, um, undeveloped area. My immediate family and my grandmother were the only Mormons in the family. The event was organized by a pair of sisters that were ancient (note the distinction from “merely old”). Anyway, part of any good family reunion in the south includes a meal. Picture a meal prepared by Aunt Bee from the Andy Griffith show times about 20. We had lots of country grandmotherly people in that family tree that loved to make people smile. Fried chicken, biscuits, casseroles, and desserts that’d make you drool all year hoping that you could get to them before the other cousins could devour them. Normally, we drank water because when I was younger, my parents would walk us through the line and fix our plate & get our beverage*. This was my first year “free of the shackles of parental oversight”. So I piled food on my plate and went to get my water. A nice relative that I didn’t know saw me, a small kid, trying to handle a plate so full of food that only a 10 yr old boy could assume he could eat it; kindly stepped in and offered me a glass with something in it. I declined and asked for water and she insisted…so I relented. I was beyond arguing with adults over seemingly small details (see Story 1). I politely took the glass and went back to my seat…and ate like I meant it. After crushing a good portion of the mountain I had collected on my plate, I reached for the glass. I had no idea what I had in front of me so I sniffed it. Not coffee, and no one would give a kid booze (there wasn’t any there but I didn’t know that)…it just smelled kinda sweet. I looked at it again. Light brown, maybe red-brown and sweet smelling. It had to be apple juice! Self assured that I was right I took a big swig and was not impressed. The juice wasn’t very fresh, but it was wet enough for me to keep eating. After finishing the plate of food and most of the glass of juice, my dad came around to the kids table and asked how everything was going. I said something like, “Great…except this juice tastes kinda off.” He told me what I’d done (remember that for Mormons, tea = bad). I felt horrible that I’d sinned (think Jew or Muslim eating pork accidentally). I ran to the bathroom crying and got sick and lost all that lovely food. *if our family wasn’t eating at home, beverage = water. My parents wouldn’t pay for soda. SUMMARY: I was a dumb kid that didn’t understand that the world didn’t revolve around me. I did and said things that now I find offensive. It is my position that everyone that lives through childhood can probably dig up stupid events where they said or did something that they look back on and think, “If I had a Delorean, I’d go back and beat the crap outta myself for even thinking that was a good idea!” TL:DR- Non-Mormons are welcome to do as they like. As the question states, “just to drink” shouldn’t bother anyone. Original Question: Are Latter-day Saints offended by others who drink tea or coffee in public (without intending to make a show of it, just to drink it)?

Nope. At least I'm not particularly offended, and it doesn't seem like the sort of thing that's worth getting worked up about. I kind of like the smell of coffee, though I've never had any. It pleasantly reminds me of the smell of burning wood, which I have also never consumed. I don't think there's a society on earth that doesn't consume a fair amount of coffee and tea. It's extremely common nearly everywhere. It might raise an internal eyebrow in a heavily-majority Mormon community, simply because it's rare, but you're still unlikely to get bothered about it. Coffee and tea are just not worth the mental energy for taking offense or getting outraged. They're not that big a deal. There's often a few coffee drinkers in Mormon congregations too, and by and large, it's treated like any other mildly unhealthy habit.

Although I’m sure counterexamples exist, I’ve never heard of a Mormon offended by someone else drinking coffee or tea (although the same isn’t true of alcohol or tobacco consumption). There are plenty of Starbucks and similar shops in Mormon-dominated Utah, and you’ll see your share of Mormons (including baristas) there, often drinking hot chocolate, herbal tea or flavored steamed milk (Mitt Romney is said to enjoy vanilla steamers). And although we in my family don’t drink coffee, we have kept some at home for when coffee-drinking guests come to visit. I can’t back this up with any official studies, but my observations would indicate that most Mormons don’t see moderate coffee drinking by nonmembers as a moral issue — and certainly not in the same category as alcohol or tobacco. Many do believe it’s unhealthy, but many also see the coffee proscription as related more to obedience or self-discipline than to health. Most who see coffee consumption as a vice recognize that as vices go it’s quite low on the list. It may interest you to know that the church-owned Polynesian Cultural Center in Hawaii has coffee (but not alcohol) on its menus — often served by Mormon students from the nearby church-operated university.

No. I am Mormon and often my non-Mormon family and friends worry they are offending me or I am going to be mad if they drink tea or coffee around me or take me somewhere that serves tea or coffee. The thing is we completely understand that is a rule for us only. We don’t expect anyone else to refrain from drinking it. We are not offended by it and we don’t have bad thoughts or feelings towards people that drink it. For us not drinking it is a show of obedience. We have been asked not to drink it so we don’t. We understand this is only a Mormon rule. We don’t expect anyone else to follow a rule set only for us. So go ahead and make a show of it - who cares? Certainly not us.

Not in the slightest. As a devout Mormon, I've always been taught that we all have freedom to make our own choices and show others kindness, love, and charity when their decisions are different than the ones I would make. If I viewed, say, you with contempt and anger for drinking tea and coffee (which many Mormons do anyways), then I would be passing a much more serious transgression than consuming an ultimately harmless substance- I would be acting contrary to Jesus Christ's own teachings and judging others for simply drinking something. In short, we really don't mind at all when others drink coffee or tea or really do anything. So long as it isn't directly affecting or harming us or people we care about, then we're completely accepting and loving. I can guarantee that.

Not in the slightest. There is nothing offensive about it. I have never heard of a member of the Church being offended by something so clearly non-offensive. I’ve bought coffee for friends, and I know Church leaders in the highest councils also do so when entertaining friends and dignitaries. My 78 year-old mother, a member since she was 13 and long-time temple worker, is meticulous about always watching every session of the semiannual General Conference as it is broadcast live from Salt Lake City. Once I asked her why she is so strict about that. She said that just in case they announce coffee is OK, she doesn’t want to miss it. Coffee drinkers are just normal people doing a normal thing.

Not in the slightest. Latter-day Saints have made a choice to not consume beverages such as Coffee and Tea (we can also add alcoholic beverages in there as well) as part of a health code called the “Word of Wisdom”. Word of Wisdom - Wikipedia You will find that adherence to the WoW is a personal and often widely varying thing. To keep it simple, when we are baptized and as part of our membership in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, we are asked to follow the Word of Wisdom. For those who are not LDS, or have not made similar covenants, there’s nothing to be offended by.

NO. As Brigham Young said: He who takes offense when no offense is intended is a fool, and he who takes offense when offense is intended is a greater fool. I can give you a hundred reasons for why alcohol is objectively terrible for the human body and for society. I still do not get offended at the sight of people drinking alcohol in public. Why would I care about coffee and tea? There are certainly various health benefits from abstaining from coffee and tea, but let’s be honest, there are numerous things that we could have in our health code that would be significantly more beneficial. I think it is clear that we were given this commandment primarily for the sake of developing discipline. That being the case, I hardly expect people outside of my faith to abstain from coffee and tea by default. That said, I do hate the smell of coffee. But that may be because there is a mental connection with my time working at a gas station.

Not even a little bit. There is nothing inherently wrong with coffee or tea, and the Word of Wisdom is just that, a word of wisdom, “given to the weakest of saints.” Adherence to the word of wisdom is a simple sign between a believer and God that they are willing to obey all his commandments, no matter how small. Those who believe that God speaks to prophets today as He has always done have the opportunity to pray about and personally determine if the Word of Wisdom in general, or avoiding coffee and tea specifically, is something that has been revealed by a prophet, and if that is something meaningful as a sign to God about such belief. Others drinking coffee and tea are not offensive at all.

Are Mormons offended by non-Mormons who drink tea or coffee in public (without intending to make a show of it, just to drink it)? I have an awesome anecdote about this one. I was in the process of applying for a job as the head of a piano department for a private music school. The school’s founder — a Mormon — and one of the other, prominent faculty members — a “non-Mormon” were at the table with me during lunch. The non-Mormon jokingly shielded her coffee with her hand from her Mormon friend, who replied, “Uh oh. Second-hand coffee. I’m going to Hell!” It was all in fun :)

Not in the slightest. Or at least I can’t imagine any Mormon being offended by that, since it doesn’t impact us in the slightest. I might be offended by your smoking if you blow it in my direction, because that’s a thoughtless inconsiderate act. But drinking coffee? You’d have to spit it out on me for me to be offended.

Ronald and I share a similar distaste for the smell of coffee, but when I worked in food service, I took pride in brewing a good cup that others enjoyed. It's no offense to me what others do that I do not—often, it is fascinating to see and hear their experiences. My restrictions are for me only and others who have taken the same upon themselves. Others are under no condemnation for they've not made the same promises.

No. If they don't belong to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS), they aren't expected to live by the same precepts that Mormons do. Even if the other person was LDS, it's not my job to be offended. I might feel sad, especially if I knew the person was struggling, but offended? No. Besides, I am much too busy trying to improve myself than to spend anytime being offended by what other people do or don't do.

No, you'll find it difficult trying to get me “offended” people drinking coffee doesn't really bother me. And I've actually had a warm cup of herbal tea before. (That's not as bad as coffee) The only thing that bothers me is when someone brews coffee, I don't know what they do but they throw away parts of the coffee beans or something. The smell is bitter, way too strong and generally awful and I hate It. Not only that but It spreads throughout the entire house! That's only my personal opinion though.

I’ve never met anyone who was offended by other people drinking coffee or tea. They just don’t want to feel pressured to drink it themselves. They might get upset about seeing another member of their church drink coffee or tea, but most people who do just do so discretely or aren’t very active. I’m sure there is someone out there who is a contradiction of this trend, but I haven’t met them yet.

I’m not. We realize we are living in a world of mortals. We try not to be of that world, but we can’t afford to be offended by little and common things like coffee and tea unless those are the only drinks available when we are attending some function. We do tend to get irritated when others smoke around us because that smoke affects our health.

I'm not Mormon, but I've known a few over the years and have yet to meet one that was outwardly offended by anything that the rest of us wouldn't be offended by. I can honestly say that the Mormons that I know are some of the kindest people I know.

No, we won't get offended. What a silly thing to get offended about! My coworkers drink quite a lot of coffee and have even shown me how to make it. Occasionally they'll forget I don't drink it and offer me some. No harm done. I'm sure there are some Latter-day Saints who get offended. There are holier-than-thou people in all religions. But for the most part, no—don't even worry about it. We sure don't. ;)

No, not really. They have a right to choose what they do, and it is definitely not my job to judge them. And, really, coffee-drinkers are the norm, not the outlier, so I don’t really have the emotional bandwidth to get offended over things like that. And honestly, by being offended by something like that, especially if I was loud about it, I would kind of be offensive myself.

I am not offended by people who smoke tobacco, who drink coffee, tea, or even alcohol. It's really none of my business. I actually enjoy the aroma of coffee beans and tobacco blends...I just want nothing to do with the end product.
Nope. Not me at least, I have friends and coworkers who drink coffee all the time, and are pretty open about it. I honestly don't care.

Heavens, no. My mom is not LDS and drinks coffee, tea, wine, etc., all the time. In fact, I've worked with LDS members who I've seen in work drinking coffee, and I would never say anything to them because that's their decision.
